Yqo_zobwW55RMtXdx5VACA.text: No longer take American Express?  Silly restaurant.  You can't take Amex for years, then suddenly stop taking Amex as part of a 'test pilot'?  This is what happens when you make silly decisions like that... bad ratings.  Don't try to cut corners to save a few pounds here and there.  Not cool inconveniencing patrons to improve the bottom line.  Besides the fact that your food is not very good (had the steak for lunch), your decision to cut Amex has lost me as a customer.

YNWZYdV_HqEPZ6BOM0qYVg.text: Three meat Sunday roast was perfect - very well cooked and a perfect portion. Super wine list with something for everyone. Reserved our table which was just as well as they looked busy. Good service. Would return.

nD34htpJGvfZ4jdBqSoVtA.text: Their smoked salmon is the best I've had in London. The roast beef was SO-SO.

RYV9mEuZ3zlRIkou4_doTg.text: Great Sunday roast. Unpretentious atmosphere but with great service anyway. Excellent value for money. Highly recommended.

9_JO9P1djaW1WMJL0knaoA.text: Came with my son on holiday. Downstairs pub is friendly & casual. Upstairs dining room is much more refined. My son started with the cod cheeks and I with the scotch egg. Both were delicious. For mains, he had the pork belly and I had lamb cooked 3 ways: chop, medallion & shepherds pie. Again, all we're wonderful. We accompanies the meal with a variety of interesting beers. Our favorite of the nit was the Old Engine Oil. Overall, we had a wonderful dinner with a great selection of beers and excellent service.

QeJ2GhVpDRgUE7vOKvW21A.text: This is one of THE places to be on Sunday for Lunch. They do an awesome mixed roast and I love it. That being said, on the last 2 occasions that I went for Sunday lunch, there were large parties there at the same time making a complete racket, which rather killed the enjoyment, and detracted from the food. Their Bloody Mary is top notch and second only to that of the Rivington Bar and Grill. If Sunday Lunch is what you want, then look no further than the Princess of Shoreditch.

hvUeoEgM8Qhac6ys37yOig.text: Princess of Shoreditch is the high princess of gastropubs in terms of proper gastropub food at non-poncey prices. Chilled-out place with truly outstanding grub. Every dish we ate (party of 16) was in one word yummy (light beetroot/ goats cheese salad to start, rib tickling tender lamb and the prize sticky toffee puddingjust to mention a few). Hmmm must go next week! (Monikasays.com)

LJbiOW2wkobaG8EyMZK06A.text: The Princess is a upmarket pub with a pleasantly decorated Farrow and Ball-esque interior, in-keeping with the building's features. They have a good selection of beers and extensive wine menu, you wont be disappointed. The wooden tables and chairs feel a little too close together, perhaps to fit in more punters? If you're wanting to go with a large group, you'd be pushed for a seat. However, the menu looked impressive, with few, but quality choice of dishes, if you don't mind paying £8.95 for a selection of delicious British cheeses and £10 for Sausage and Mash. They also have a upper floor restaurant for dining.

pSYq87Jk73XpMP-gf41QCg.text: This place is still good. Went there about 2 months ago, and typically didn't remind myself where it was. The extra walking about to find the place gave me just the right appetite - try it!

4q79dP8iFyxnWxM8rSCUgA.text: I had a lovely experience here, but perhaps it was because I didn't have the roast (which seemed overpriced to me). The staff were very friendly and sat us quite quickly for a busy Sunday. My friend had the really tasty beetroot risotto, and I had the broccoli/ginger/sesame soup of the day that was awesome, and a smoked haddock fishcake with poached egg, which I loved. It was the perfect amount of food. We shared a carafe of wine (love that option) and were in an out quickly but not rushed. Really enjoyed my experience. Only gripe is it is on the pricier end.

Radp2tAt3ommVhIc5cZ_tQ.text: Was visiting London for the first time and met up for dinner with a friend who lives in the neighborhood.  We started with the black pudding, it was very well seasoned and came with a perfectly poached egg.  I'm a sucker for anything topped with an egg and the black pudding paired with the runny egg yolk was delicious.  For my main I had the burger with a white truffle mayo, tomato chutney, and foie gras.  It was incredibly rich and very satisfying.  For dessert I had the sticky toffee pudding which provided the perfect sweet bite after the rich burger.  I'd definitely return and would recommend this place to friends in the area.

nIlgK6RLSGLTPoyQ_Nt3Pw.text: While in London we stayed a short distance away from this restaurant. On several occasions, we appreciated a queue and so we were intrigued. On a recent Sunday night, we saw no line and walked into the main floor portion of the restaurant and an immediate access to the last open table. Our waiter was excellent, attentive, and friendly. He explained that restaurant bottles their own still and sparkling water and donate the proceeds from the water to charity. We were most impressed with the salmon and the beef main courses. Nicely flavored and cooked as requested. The fillet of sole was just okay. The crème brûlée was incredible. They had a good selection of wines. I think the restaurant was priced appropriately.

dQ5m9owkC_mp1ImtHw9vBQ.text: we didn't come for the sunday roast, so i can't comment on that, but we did stop in for a drink.  the bar is super cute, and since it was afternoon, a pimm's cup was appropriate (it was the wimbledon finals after all).  the atmosphere is nice, and we came between the lunch and dinner rush.  i saw the roasts go by to other people, and they did look good.

4huLr8b5pIFIKuzhK_cOog.text: Really quite disappointing. I booked the upstairs restaurant on a Sunday afternoon. They were full upstairs and downstairs. They left us to wait for our table while they presumably reorganised the upstairs - despite my booking and confirmation phone call. I ordered the roast beef, my friends the mixed roast. At £15 and £15.50 respectively I had high expectations. I was let down - the veges were luke warm, bordering on cold. Not much gravy. The meat was good - but again, not hot. I wondered how long our plates had been sitting waiting for someone to serve. Service - its was only just ok. When they took away our main plates.... were were ignored for the next 1/2 hour- no question of did we want more drinks/dessert/bill. Just simply not acknowledged at all. I had to flag someone down to tell them we did actually want to see the dessert menu and order another round. With a service charge included at 12.5% and the fact the upstairs is the "restaurant" I actually expected to be waited on! For the prices, and reviews around I had definitely expected better. Much better.

o2UCaDNlcicR_k_hves0AQ.text: The Princess has established itself as a top dining experience in Shoreditch, combining a gastropub, serving classic pub dishes, in the downstairs bar area, with more of a fine dining experience in the upstairs dining room. Book ahead for the fine dining, or turn up early for the walk in downstairs. The Princess has a lengthy wine list, with many by the glass and carafe options.

vXN_LEyym0horOqeR_64xA.text: I have tried to enter the pub area a couple of times and have found it better to come earlier rather than later. Service is okay but on a very busy night can grow much too slow for a hungry group or even couple. Food is okay -- although the upstairs dining is much better. What turns me off the most is how some customers act after much too many pints. I've been in less "gastropub"/ rawer places in the area that encourage a more amiable crowd that can control their liquor. I like drinking but I don't like watching people falling everywhere or saying rude things. It's a big turn off. I come to a place to enjoy the food and drink -- not to listen to customers' repressed emotions.

82JqEAlHxox6t72-L4P5xg.text: A very hip pub in Shoreditch with a room upstairs that is equally as impressive as the downstairs. In addition to a large selection of beer, they have a blackboard chalked full of great wines by the glass. They serve pub fare downstairs while the dining room serves more traditional Brit grub like pork belly, which is richly fabulous. Like many of the pubs in the area, it becomes packed by city workers from 5 to 7. Great to go anytime for drinks or a great meal.

t2-6j6L1hWuBeb45AHWcfg.text: Came here for dinner with a big group of friends last fall. I believe it was £25 prix fixe for three meals.I ordered this pork belly dish that was one of the best pork belly I had ever tasted. It was so, so succulent and melted in your mouth, the way that braised meat should be. I don't remember what appetizer or dessert I ordered, so I guess they weren't as memorable, haha.The reason why I'm only giving it three stars is because first, they required a down payment (NOT a deposit). What?!? For a big group, I understand wanting some kind of security in the event of cancellation, but no restaurant I've eaten at has ever asked for money UP FRONT. Normally they take a credit card and apply some penalty charge if we don't show up. So strange. Secondly, one of our friends got stuck at work and couldn't make it to dinner, so we asked them to wrap up her steak so she could eat it later. They literally just rolled it in a ball of foil that later leaked all over the inside of her bag. We ordered her a side dish of greens which was never wrapped up. I know that asking to get food wrapped up at the end isn't as common in the UK and Europe as it is in America but... surely for a more upscale place like this, the request wasn't so rare that they wouldn't have takeaway containers on hand?

photos.caption: Photo of The Princess of Shoreditch - London, United Kingdom. epic pork belly dish

I0gKp_lcl_iZ-p2kzZtDAg.text: Great gastropub - loved the food.We came on a Saturday around 6pm and it was packed.  It's less bar and more restaurant as the bar area is small and smashed up next to the tables.  But by the time we left folks didn't care and the bar area was packed.The downstairs dining is first come first serve tables and has a more limited menu than the dining room upstairs.  Upstairs takes reservations and books up pretty quickly.We ordered and loved:Roasted butternut squash, spinach & artichoke wellington, garlic mushrooms (v) £11.958oz Hereford beef burger, pickles, double dipped chips  £11.95They also had a good and affordable beer selection.We would definitely go back.

LsA_C9h8xjPguhTi8YAIwQ.text: As promised, I returned for Sunday Roast!With a group of 10, many visiting from out of town -- we wanted to show them a proper Sunday Roast, and the dear Princess had been singing her siren song (Kamm & Sons cocktail, for the record) for weeks since my last visit. The Roast was absolutely delightful! Raves all around. The service was quite exceptional as well. Very friendly, fun and swift from start to finish. My mother and I split the Guineafowl Roast (for 2) -- and at 25 quid, very reasonable. Everyone was picking off our plates, a very large portion and delicious. There were various mixed roasts, roast beef, duck and lentil salads, and the list goes on. End with Sticky Toffee with ice cream and a Rhubarb Custard Crumble. And rose champagne. And coffee. And...stuffed! The perfect Roast. So why only 4-stars? Well, it was a surefire 5 if not for a few issues with the private booking. But other than this, it was absolutely lovely and I'll surely return for another Roast. Not one complaint in the bunch. Just beautiful! Private Party Booking: *Tip -- make one for Sunday Roast, this place is busy. I made a booking for our large group, Sunday 4pm. For parties over 8 they require a 10 quid/pp deposit and a set menu. This was handled by Duncan, and all went very smoothly. Form is quite easy to fill out, deposit charged to my credit card, etc. A few missteps with the booking: Our party all arrived on time (nice!) and our table was ready upstairs in the dining room, but when our last remaining 3 came they were told it wasn't ready even though we were all upstairs and they gave our name. This delayed them a good 10 minutes as they waited and thought we were not there. The table was a bit crunched, despite the advanced booking and missing one place setting/chair, which had to be placed on the end. Then...no set menu? We asked and they were confused. "Oh no, we only do that for dinner, you can do a la carte." Which, actually worked better for us, but after all the fuss with the private booking and the set menu (which was sent to me on PDF) -- this seemed strange. Finally, the 100GBP deposit was not taken off the bill. I had to ask for it to be subtracted. All in all, I wondered if anyone actually had even told them we were coming. For a booking where I had to do a fair bit of prep, form-filling, depositing, etc...I expected a bit more. I'll be back though, probably with just a smaller group!

5WUP6VUPjYH5DKzqfZ6m1A.text: Just far enough from the City to still be easy after work, but avoids (for the most part) the hordes of pinstripes spilling from its seams that every pub in the City seems to suffer from.I've only been for drinks, but I thought the service was very good, it's less rammed than most after work joints, and had a small bit of outdoor seating, which I always appreciate.

wyp6L83NhY_NYUX40KBZJg.text: Definitely recommend the upstairs restaurant  - fantastic value for money in an often overpriced part of town.

NQeBn2OA8eUsOTcHTB0ciw.text: 3 stars just cuz I've never had an English wine (we DID discuss at LENGTH how they care for grapes in this climate), and ended up with a lovely one from Gloucester here.  3 Choirs, is what's UP.Sea bass was c-c-c-coooooooold but tasty.  Good thing I was hungers, cuz nothing was going to stop things going into the mouth at that point.  Veggie gnocci was super light yet flavorful...and fried blue cheese?  GET IN MY BELLY.    Do book tables for the upstairs dining room if you'd like a bit o' comfy chatting volume as the pub area gets swamped with the suits.Add a sticky toffee pudding top off, for an uncomfortable walk home.

9V584Ax33LobUbMHU53vcQ.text: I like this place so why 3 stars? This is a busy East London pub / restaurant near Great Eastern Road. The pub has always been busy downstairs when I've been. The restaurant upstairs is accessible by a spiral staircase which brings you into a tidy but tight restaurant area Service was attentive, perhaps a little too attentive but makes a pleasant change from many other places. Now back to the 3 stars...,the food is very nice. We shared a smoked salmon starter and I followed with a ribeye steak cautiously ordered medium and it actually came out medium rather than me having to lasso the meat from the plate. But, and this is the small but, the servings were tiny. Pricey and tiny. The ribeye seemed as though it had been sliced through the middle to make two portions (it seemed as though I had one half and someone got the other), the home made  chips were maliciously cut chunks of potatoes deep fried and lightly garnished with some vegetable matter. The side of chard did not appeal to me. The wine was ok, but scarily overpriced when cross referenced against Vivino (£7 average price versus £38 restaurant price). The dessert, now required, was also petite. Calling the portion microscopic would be a little unfair. So better value found elsewhere with less of a climb to the meal.

94kPrHOHz5nSbYrTZwWenw.text: Great service as always,  decent burger,  could have done with a few more fries but then I am greedy.  Nicely busy and good venue to meet my clients.

GRpDW5ZJQFTa1iKfKzd-aQ.text: After reading up the reviews, we had been expecting this place to be packed for Sunday lunch.  We booked ahead and when we got there, it was almost empty!  We were the only ones in the upstairs room for lunch.I had the pork belly, which is my usual choice.  It was as good as any of the others that I have had, which is to say that it's good - I've usually enjoyed my Sunday roasts here.  The pork was alright, but a bit fatty.  The potatoes could have been a bit crunchier.  But, I liked the yorkshires - smaller than usual, but I prefer it when you can use them to mop up the gravy.The serve was friendly.  The price was about average for what I have experienced.

GZaQ-C4pItAPF2mmRg5mVg.text: This place is pretty out-of-the-way for me on any normal day, but we ventured in last night after work (in The City) and before jazz (in Dalston)... Shoreditch being sort of equidistant between the two. Like others have said, it gets really busy with post-workers from The City. Because the crowd was spilling out into the side street, we decided the best plan of attack was dinner in the much more civilized dining room upstairs. The menus are pretty much the same, though the pub grub (i.e. cottage pie, fish n' chips) are only served downstairs.Of course, this brilliant plan only worked for about thirty minutes before enormous groups of suits started appearing to commence 'work dinners.' It was a lovely half-hour, though. The space is subdued, open, and bright with a large fireplace on one end and the wrought iron spiral staircase at the other. And the food was just as lovely.I had the soup of the day, a pureed pea and ham number that was divine. My main of grilled sea bass in yellow pepper and tomato gazpacho was fab. It tasted just as delicious as the fish and gazpacho I love in southern Spain. The hubs' duck and chicken terrine was bland, but the steak and chips he had after were done beautifully. We washed it all down with a reasonably priced bottle of French rose. It was an excellent meal.The only real fault I could find was the fact that there is no toilet upstairs, which means you must navigate the (precarious after a couple drinks) staircase to use the one in the pub. On the upside, however, I noticed their advertisement on the back of the stall door for a pretty nice lunch deal (the dinner menu just with the lighter options) of 2-courses for 14 pounds or 3-courses for 18. Not a bad offering, especially if you work in The City and are looking for a lovely sit-down lunch.

JWVVyIhUDpq8UYDOqNhHIg.text: I have been going here quite often on a Sunday of late as I just can't get enough of the lovely food, great location and the Bloody Mary cocktails! I quite agree that their Bloody Mary takes some beating - as does their rather extensive and reasonably priced wine list. I usually opt for the mixed roast as it has a bit of everything and everything is cooked well. The homemade condiments are a must, especially the homemade horseradish. I would recommend booking in advance as otherwise you will have to wait at least an hour for a table.

photos.caption: Photo of The Princess of Shoreditch - London, United Kingdom

k-Q9NyMHBCuHTIgnbVoDgQ.text: Went for the Sunday roast and tried the mixed roast with roast beef and pork and some organic chicken. It was good but I have had better in London. The portion was quite generous and should leave most people feeling full afterwards. The interior of the place is worth going for though, very light and airy with tables that are not too closely packed together.

photos.caption: Photo of The Princess of Shoreditch - London, United Kingdom. Mixed roast

Bfemter7NPyB-GX5XWau-Q.text: Good plat but more salt according to me. The price is a little high but the decoration is friendly, I like

photos.caption: Photo of The Princess of Shoreditch - London, United Kingdom

ghjs67jiBvsYFaB47NpCBg.text: I was actually here on a launch night, which meant complimentary canapés and vino which makes my recollection of the evening somewhat blurry. The Princess of Shoreditch was recently re-furbished by owners Scott Hunter (Loungelover Group) and Maria Larsen (Corney & Barrow Wine Bars) in the hope of offering something a little different from the standard 'gastropub' fayre found all over London. It does succeed somewhat, it's very pretty but I am yet to feel it distinguishes itself from residing neighbours. However, it does not sell bottled water, one step further to reducing that carbon footprint.

photos.caption: Photo of The Princess of Shoreditch - London, United Kingdom

jZ6dmddhLxc_0Nm6rz4Jzg.text: What a great spot. We got to the pub an hour before our dinner reservations on a rainy Saturday. Our initial thought was that we'd stroll around and see the neighborhood before dinner, but the rain made us consider a pint or glass of wine instead. The place was packed and the only possible table was a large group that was clearing out as we arrived. When we started to take over, the GM (Dan) politely let us know the table was reserved for another expected group. We told him we were early for our dinner reservations and he quickly changed gears and invited us to sit at the vacant table while he notified the dining room we were early and prepared for the upcoming party. He provided wine and beer via table service and reset the table while we waited for the dining room to re-open. Soon, our table was ready and we ascended the spiral staircase and enjoyed a fantastic dinner. Very possibly the best lamb I've ever had. The dining room is a great contrast to the noisy/hip pub below and the service was refined, but not stuffy. If you are looking for a fantastic meal and experience while exploring London's hottest neighborhood, there's no need to look any further.

siou-aIFO6RS3LqzAulnAA.text: Mmm... Sunday roast. I was ravenous upon arrival, and fully satiated by the time we left. Because I'm indecisive, I got the mixed roast with chicken, beef, and pork, and it was perfect. I'm not normally a veggie fan, but I even ate those because they were so good. It took us a minute to find this place, but it was definitely worth all the Google mapping. A little pricey, but the ingredients are clearly fresh and high quality.

3-QT1qfgTP1f4yGQPKozbA.text: Great food. Comfy decor and superb service. The fish pie is immense.

8XEc94EkDO2aLmzMooN79Q.text: The Princess is a charming little pub near the convergence of Shoreditch and its antithesis, the City, which is blessed with hands down the best wallpaper I've ever seen in a pub.Whimsical equine wallpaper aside - and believe me, it's a sight to behold - The Princess is an aesthetically pleasing little pub with a great wine menu, cool, hot staff and a nice, unobvious location just a little off the beaten track.

photos.caption: Photo of The Princess of Shoreditch - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Princess of Shoreditch - London, United Kingdom

qG_8ykd4a-6Fxe2q-sBZJg.text: Came here for Christmas lunch yesterday. The pub downstairs was packed, and I was relieved to be seated upstairs in the dining room. The staff were very friendly and clearly extremely busy. I acknowledge that there was some measure of mass-production going on, and this review takes the time of year into account. I had the parsnip soup which was tasteless & under seasoned. I couldn't manage more than a couple of spoonfuls. Next I had the turkey. This was reasonably moist but very fatty. The vegetables were nothing special. The custard tart followed: rubbery. They have a good wine list, but even so, I'm not rushing back.

oxK3vpdkOuYfe7SZjgSPnQ.text: My my, what a pretty little pub we have here! Humbly tucked away down Paul street (turn right at the cow rubbish bins, straight on 'til morning...), it feels about as far away from Shoreditch as Hampstead's famed Holly Bush, which can be fantastic or tragic, based on your personal preferences. Although bit on the pricey side, this was certainly one of the finest Sunday Roasts I've had here in London. However as the meal was ending, we were asked to move tables... apparently to make room for a group of 5 who had walked in...   ? It was very odd as the three of us had a reservation... and were literally half way through our £90 meal. Perhaps this was a 5-star move for the folks waiting, but it was definitely a star detractor for me.

RAtX7gRK-wW5DOUZxchD7A.text: We had a very nice dinner here upstairs via the iron winding stairs.  Great gastro pub with the sort of food that will please everyone and they had a decent selection of real ale on offer.  Staff were great and finished with a nice old school desert.

Ah9Vjh9PpBSNM_GdDKB9IQ.text: A beautiful little pub away from the main Shoreditch drag.  It is less of a boozer and more of a serious foodie place which may explain it being less busy when most pubs and bars in the area are buzzing with crowds of people spilling out into the streets.I have been here twice now and will make a bee-line again when next in the area.  On the first occasion a friend and I met up here ahead of a party to enjoy a quick catch up.  I returned last Thursday after a couple of private view events at some nearby galleries.  It was the hottest day of the year so far and most people were hanging out on the pavement but we were happy to find a seat indoors to relax.The menu is rather ambitious with descriptions bordering on the pretentious - oh well, this is the heart of hipsterville after all.  We just wanted a bit of a snack and opted for starters and sides only - pleased to report that staff were happy with this, no minimum orders at least not failry late in the evening.  Apparently they aim at high quality ingredients that are sustainably sourced, and my asparagus was a perfect example.  Not exactly cheap at £8 for a small plate but still better value than my friend's 'umami' salad that came in the tiniest of bowls.It's a beautiful little place and I hope next time I'll get to sample one of the mains - or just another quick drink on my way to or from somewhere else.

L7odlcW6URsbI9xwaAxNfA.text: It's literally my favorite place to have Sunday roast in London. I've tried a few,  but this is the best. The lamb roast is fantastic if you don't want to try the chicken or beef. The sticky toffee pudding is amazing! One of the best in London. I used to live across the strret from this place and whenever I go back, I have such fond memories of my time living in London. :)

BEI1WA0dCqUbAXkrlNa02w.text: Overpriced gastropub, with extremely small portions, in the middle of Shoreditch.Don't expect to feel full after eating here - food is like having fingerfood for your drink, but paying it as having a dinner in a Michelin restaurant. The environment, though, downstairs/upstairs is relaxed and the service is satisfactory.

photos.caption: Photo of The Princess of Shoreditch - London, United Kingdom. The Princess of Shoreditch

DITr63igNGJmuRdHugJ64w.text: OH.....EM......GEE, I wish the Shoreditch Princess was in the states!! Sunday Supper is the best - Yorkshire pudding over roast beef & Sticky Toffee Pudding for dessert. If 'pudding' is in the name, you can bet it'll be delicious!

KNm2lsDejDvyYNomoGG22w.text: The best Sunday roast I've had. The portions are huge!

gRSeFB20ev0Lv_HRhpdAGA.text: Style over substance gastropub close to Old Street. We found the service a little off - when I asked if they served dessert the bar person just said "Yep" and then I had to ask to see a menu. A little initiative wouldn't hurt. The sticky toffee pudding was overpriced and tiny, although redeemed slightly by the generous amount of sauce. Sharing between two was tough.Our pal's burger wasn't great - he described it as managing to be both burnt and raw. When we were ready to leave, the waiter studiously ignored us so that I had to go up to the bar and ask for the bill - even though they claimed it was table service. 3/5 for food. 2/5 for service. Meh.

FJ-0QTeANyJe6hgv6hPSgA.text: My experience here couldn't have been better. The beer selection was nice. The staff were first class. I arrived before they started serving dinner. I was hungry early. So, I enjoyed a nice drink and as soon as possible, they started my food. I got the 28-day-aged hanger steak with béarnaise & triple-cooked chips. It was prepared perfectly. The place is casual is a great way. Excellent food, service, location and a nice room. The prices were very good as well.

kZquelCtD14JJzWx9Ib-jA.text: Came here for a birthday dinner.  Ordered everything on the menu.  Porkkchops, sea bass , chicken.    Great service.  Food was absolutely horrible. After all we went through to get reservations.  Good luck.

G6_5clgWVEOMDkIqunUqpQ.text: This was undoubtedly the most delicious meal I have experienced since moving to London for the summer. My friend and I each ordered the Sunday roast; she had the sirloin and I had the lamb. To begin, the waitstaff was extremely friendly and we felt right at home. A few pints of cidre were served right away while my friend and I debated between the pork, lamb and beef. When the massive portions arrived in front of us, we were in awe. One of the waitstaff came over with a plate full of different sauces/accompaniments. For my lamb, I got the mint sauce which was amazing and my friend the mustard. The waiter was very helpful in making recommendations as to which we should pair with our proteins. The potatoes were incredible--delightfully crisp on the outside while light and creamy on the inside. The vegetables were perfectly cooked, the Yorkshire pudding was light and flaky and delicious and the gravy was great!We finished the meal with some classic sticky toffee pudding that was divine!Overall it was somewhat pricey, but DEFINITELY worth every penny.

photos.caption: Photo of The Princess of Shoreditch - London, United Kingdom. Sticky Toffee Pudding.
Photo of The Princess of Shoreditch - London, United Kingdom. Sunday Roast. Background: Sirloin. Foreground: Lamb.

Gfaq27usTG2LBV_DCD6B_Q.text: Fish n chips! Came here with 4 coworkers, and 3/5 of us ordered the fish and chips. The fish is perfectly fried with an even, golden crispy skin and tender white flesh that just falls apart when you cut into it. I have never seen such elegantly prepared fast food.We started with two kinds of chips (fries for all ye 'muricans). There was a VERY thick cut version and a thinner version more akin to McDonald's fries (please don't shoot daggers at me for mentioning Micky-Dees). I thought the thinner chips were tastier, but that's just my preference.The fish n chips come with mushy peas, which helped balance out the greasiness of the food. Loved loved loved the mayo sauce for dipping the chips in. I got a dry white wine that the bartender recommended. I told him that I prefer a dry white that's not sweet or sour. He gave me a look that told me he knew exactly what I wanted, and he was right. It was so refreshing and crisp. I ordered seconds but alas, I don't recall the name of the wine.

eA2Mmek8AeQ_WouwqL7gzw.text: So I went to The Princess of Shoreditch for my friend's birthday gathering. After getting off the bus...I wandered around and finally found the place (it's not that hard to find). Let me just say...I was slightly puzzled as to how to get to the second floor of the building because that's where the group was already seated. I saw the spiral staircase and the door to it...but I normally think that those doors are usually locked right? Anyway after wandering into the side entrance I inched my way through the VERY packed downstairs area...up to the second floor. This was an interesting feat because those spiral stairs are a bit tricky...especially with heels...Anyway the party was seated at the large table in the corner and thankfully I wasn't the last to arrive. NOW TO THE FOOD...they have a daily menu I believe and it looked pretty good!I ordered the 3 course menu meal...but at the time...I chose 2...The menu offered the following selections:2 courses for £25 or 3 courses for £30.50starters: Roasted golden beetroot soup, chives (v)Globe artichoke, smoked garlic mayo (v)Potted crab, avocado, mango salsa Rabbit rillettes, cornichons toastmains:Jerusalem artichoke, risotto, baby spinach, taleggio (v)slow roasted pork belly ,braised cheek, black pudding croquetteSole, sautéed potatoes (something else)28 day aged sirloin, watercress, double dipped chips, red wine jusdesserts:caramelized peaches, homemade vanilla ice cream sticky toffee pudding, toffee sauce, homemade vanilla ice creamCheese platechocolate fondant, homemade vanilla ice creamI ordered the Potted Crab...it was small...but delicious (nothing to really complain or rave about) and then the slow roasted pork belly because the waiter suggested it...he said you can get delicious steak anywhere but you can't get really well cooked pork belly anywhere! Let me just say...it was GOOD! (so was the steak...but that's a different matter) and the caramelized peaches...those were meh...I am a fan of this place because they never really rush you for anything and we had a very nice dinner. My friends all loved their dishes and yes...THEY WERE GOOD! I think given another chance...i'd go again! :) (I have nothing really to say about the pub portion downstairs because...I didn't go...but like I said earlier, IT WAS PACKED so I'm assuming it was a great)

8SjZpV9v_2mSrLJ3aMnxyA.text: Are you looking for a Sunday roast with the largest Yorkshire pudding you've ever seen? Look no further than the Princess of Shoreditch. I haven't been to many Sunday roast spots in East London, but I'd definitely go back to the PoS. It's a little pricey, and I've been told you get a little less than you used to, but overall the food was very good. Lots of good bottles of beer to go with it as well, and a pretty good sticky toffee pudding to top it all off!

xtvAsm6gsKSUWNn_cKrQfg.text: Very solid Sunday lunch in an area where I would not expect such a nice pub and dining room. Very nice lambRoast with a good mix of sides. Sticky toffee pudding was excellent. Good wine selection. Can be pricey but there was definitely some extra care over and above a regular pub. Six of us came in two hours early and the wait accommodated us.

6mipsT1W0o0ETeBXH5QWhw.text: I received word about The Princess from across the pond, dutifully bookmarking it for some later relevant date. Since that time I've tried reserving for Sunday lunch several times without success (I've said it before and I'll say it again: all good Sunday roasts in London must be booked in advance.)Then finally one Sunday, just as the clocks had sprung forward, I snagged a  table for three. Our roasts were bountiful, the meat tender - Yorkshire puds wet on the inside -  and arrived with lots of veg on the plate: beets, broccoli, carrots and parsnips.Both upstairs and down are bathed in light during the day and the service is pleasant. Guinness is on tap, if you're like me and enjoy a glass of the black stuff with your roast. And thus, The Princess of Shoreditch joins my regular Sunday lunch rotation.

photos.caption: Photo of The Princess of Shoreditch - London, United Kingdom

hBpExonIl3D6y7AZdyLkmQ.text: Came here to grab some eats and start our night out. It was busy but not so many people that you can't move. The lighting was perfect, music was chill. Great vibe and atmosphere for a chill night out with friends. We grabbed drinks at the bar and waited about 20 minutes for a table. We had the fish and chips, SO DELICIOUS! Our server was pretty attentive. Overall, great experience.

vzyjjHC5Osx53pCFOkFOTA.text: I came here for my work Christmas party this year. The menu sounded promising and so did the location. We had a table for twelve in the upstairs dining area.I had the duck rillettes, the venison and cheese for dessert. The rillettes were nice but not amazing. The venison was overcooked and the brussels sprouts that came with it were really underdone. The cheese was good, but it's hard to screw up cheese.I had a beer when I arrived, but wasn't impressed. We did end up ordering some nice wine to accompany our meal too. I guess my problem was everything was just nice, and not amazing. It was probably better than other pubs I go to and eat at, which is saying something. However, given the hefty £40 pp price of the three course meal, I was really expecting something better. It's as if the chef really wants to be working someplace nicer and is trying to hard. Yes it's a gastropub, but really the flavor and level of cooking should come first, then trying to make it look pretty. And the plating wasn't really even that pretty. My friend ordered the salmon. And if there are cubes of beetroot stacked on a plate, that means it's gourmet right?

88xwIQ2LLuuCpQDodwvg5Q.text: Popped in for a few beers with some mates, the downstairs bar is a really nice space with the right amount of chairs and tables. The bar has a decent amount of largers from all over the world (although nothing local!?!?) I wasn't really looking but I don't think the Ale choice is brilliant. There seemed to be a nice choice of spirits and mixers if that's your thing. I also treated the lads to some mixed nuts which were a great accompanyment to the beers. The bar staff were a nice bunch and offered table service..... I'm never too sure about this in London pubs, there's sonthing weird about being served beer at your table in a pub and I'm always suspicious they are going to add an annoying service charge, as we were 1 meter from the bar I played it safe and ordered there.I've eaten upstairs previously and its not bad, probably not as good as they would like to think but above standard pub grub.

uhltC8_QAq_tf8dkRSXzUA.text: If you are visiting from 'merica you must try a Sunday roast. No excuses. This was the most memorable meal I ate while in London. A very hearty meal, best shared with friends and family, will make you one happy person.Skip the Bloody Mary's especially the concoction with beets since its tough to chew a drink. They arrive in a short glass for around five pounds, no garnish, and seem like an afterthought. The Yorkshire pudding were so large my camera recognized it as a face. They are a great vessel for soaking up all the meaty juices left behind. The mixed roast came with pork, beef, and chicken. You can never go wrong with potatoes finished in duck fat. The veggies were perfectly cooked, sweet, and were not part of the dish you push to the side. Great service and a wonderful experience. The sticky toffee ice cream dessert was unnecessary but warranted. This was the tipping point to the inevitable food coma. I wish I had a place like this at home. Cheers to The Princess of Shoreditch.

photos.caption: Photo of The Princess of Shoreditch - London, United Kingdom. Guineafowl for two
Photo of The Princess of Shoreditch - London, United Kingdom. Mixed roast

hZfUDI0LAKQjtsFmGYMkvw.text: Not bad. We popped in for a late-ish dinner on Sunday night - the place was crowded but the owner thought he could fit us in before the kitchen closed. Not 10 minutes later, we had a table.The food was good but portions were a bit out of whack. The beef roast was a good-sized piece of meat accompanied by three large potatoes, a good amount of carrots and popover- type biscuit. The hake, had a tiny bit of potatoes, a sauce and nothing else. Hmmm...Wine prices were reasonable, no beer sampled.
